> [fke13](#comment_126_1DZBbYJmuFQvVTe2X2Enrveziw3vN1JQXz): The very advantages, why the ZeroNet was created at first place: decentralization, data replication, data redundancy. The anti-censorship measures can be seen a lot like in military terms "security" can be seen in terms of multiple, individual tasks that jointly provide the proper security. For example, part of the anti-censorship measure is data redundancy: blow up a datacenter or "confiscate" the servers, but data is in many places, too many places to "confiscate" or to blow up. Switch off the Internet, but if the zites have been previously downloaded like podcasting MP3-files, then people can read the forums/blogs even, when there is no internet connection. Securing something against attackers should be seen as a modular task that has sub-tasks. The ZeroNet has its role and the Tor has its role and the 2 together make a nice whole. > [filips](#comment_389_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): Sites are meant to be dynamic, so it is normal and correct that site owner can change them.
If I agreed with all the design decisions for ZeroNet I wouldn't have made this thread now would I? It seems to me that making it that way is shoehorning the model of the old web where the developers control the hardware and thus de facto have full control over the content, in a situation where the users control the hardware and thus should be the only ones having full control over the content. IMO for sites where users contribute to the optional data, there should be more separation of software and data, with the same content provided by users being accessible through different client software. So for instance if the ZeroTalk developer is hit by a bus, we should be able to fork ZeroTalk's code and continue tapping off the same database of posts as if nothing had happened. After all, unlike with a traditional site, we all have access to and help host the database, so the site's developer shouldn't have exclusive rights when it comes to using it.
For instance, if that functionality existed I'd already forked 08chan, since the developer is missing in action right now, and before that he was a massive fuckup anyway even though he had quite a decent number of users. So much that the users of his site had to modify the site's files and set them read only to get an usable experience since he was too much of a retard/pussy to install a more recent version of the Millchan imageboard engine.
Again, the reason clearnet sites die even with thousands of users when the owner goes away is that they physically own irreplaceable parts of the infrastructure -mainly the right to set what the root DNS servers return when queried for his domain, PHP or otherwise server side code, and database-. With ZeroNet the last two are in possession of the users by necessity already, and there's no DNS, only public key digests that should refer strictly to the software and not to the content. The content should probably be addressed by randomly generated UUIDs that are agreed to refer to a certain database (the collection of optional files which right now is associated to the same public key digest that the javascript code is).
But again, if I was in charge I'd begin by making sites not update automatically by default, and adding a requirement that all site updates provide a changelog of at least 10 characters every time they're updated or the update wouldn't be recognized as valid.
>And you can already click "Pause" button on ZeroHello to disable site updates.
Oh, ok. I was under the impression that also stopped user generated content, is that not so?

> [filips](#comment_390_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): This already exists and is already used in ZeroMe and other sites (merged sites / hubs). [...]

> [filips](#comment_391_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): That's basically content-addressed data and that "randomly generated UUIDs" are often hashes of content.

Well, the thing is, in this case the "content" would be the whole set of posts, so the hash for the "content" would be constantly changing.
So I don't see any other solution than the site's code just telling ZN "save that buch of signed data I gave you to the distributed storage location addressable by this arbitrary string" (or retrieve from). The act of retrieving or writing to that location would cause ZN to download the data stored in that location from other clients and begin seeding it and updating it just like a regular site.
Edit: but content assessable content still would be very nice for deduplication purposes.
